ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about critical race theory, settler colonialism, and how to think critically about texts, poetry and writing that I had never even considered before. Through the projects and presentations, I learned how to become a better and more aware writer and reader. I learned how to discuss and read academic and critical texts and apply them to poetry and prose, which I had never done before.

I learned how to think critically about the portrayal of indigenous people, their efforts to reclaim ownership/autonomy over their stories, and the modes of resistance employed by Native authors in their poetry to further this process. Also, I have a new found admiration for spatial features of poetry that many of these poets have used.

Professor Hickey is incredible at teaching and selecting texts that shift your understanding of Indigeneity and settler colonialism through the lens of poetic expression. We discussed so many different ideas and epistemologies that have really changed how I approach the world and think about things like power and loneliness and sex.
I read a LOT of AMAZING poetry by Indigenous authors and had really great discussions.
I learned to evaluate poems and theory critically and together and I also developed my writing skills
This class was one of the best I've taken at Yale. I learned about how to think critically about poetry and also gained immense understanding of indigenous issues and settler colonialism.

In some ways this is a survey course of Indigenous Poetics. In order to make sense of the poetry, we read theory alongside it both the poetry and the theory complement each other in unique ways. The topics we discuss are so important, and (unfortunately) so unique at a place like Yale.
Exposure to poetry written by Native poets, bodies of theory on poetic practice and indigenous politics.

I learned how to think critically about the obstacles that Indigenous, non-settler populations in the U.S. and other settler-colonial nations face.  These barriers include, and are certainly not limited to, the ways that publishing companies and political agendas can influence and determine what stories may be widely told, who can tell their stories and what ways they can be told, and what information may be withheld and changed (by the story-telling populations, as well as the editors who influence the ways certain stories are be structured).  The course also reinforced the importance of viewing history as a culmination of iterative structures versus one-and-done events.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Alanna Hickey!!! She is the sweetest, most encouraging, and most knowledgeable professor at this university.  
weaknesses: Literally none, I learned so much and this was my favorite class this semester.

Strengths: Prof. Hickey and the poets included in the Syllabus. 

Weaknesses: The reading was sometimes a bit long (esp w/ the secondary readings) but Prof. Hickey was able to adjust her syllabus like the queen that she is to address this workload during this hard semester.

Everything was an open conversation and Professor Hickey made it clear that we could come to her if the workload was too high or needed adjustment and I feel that those changes were made with the number of readings we were assigned around the middle of the semester.

Professor Hickey has created an amazing, welcoming, and intellectually stimulating class that I absolutely loved. The course covers a broad survey of really interesting poetry collections that scans some of the thematic motifs in Indigenous poetry (queer/feminist Indigeneity, Indigenous futurisms, etc.). Prof Hickey organized the class in a way that really builds community between students and puts all ideas in conversation with each other. I really enjoyed the brief check-ins at the beginning that made me feel more grounded and helped create connections between students. The student-led discussions were really fun and helped make it feel like the conversations were ours, with help from Prof Hickey to smooth over transitions and link ideas. I really loved this course and can't think of something I would change.
Professor Hickey is absolutely amazing and really made this class interesting. Poetry was great and the assignments were really accommodating, which was so great this for semester!

I loved this course!

Strengths: thoughtfully organized syllabus, reading great poetry, Prof Hickey fosters a wonderful class environment and is incredibly understanding and responsive to student feedback and input of all kinds. the main weakness was I wish we'd done more work so discussions could have gone more in depth, so the fact that I wished we had done more reading hopefully tells you something about how special this course and professor are

Weaknesses: we chose as a class to make the theory readings optional. I hope in future in-person classes they're either mandatory or strongly encouraged because I got a lot out of reading them and wished we could have spent less time in student presentations on the theory and more time discussing both the poems & theory in conversation with each other! But despite this I still loved the course
No weaknesses. This course was incredible. I learned so much without stressing too much about it.

This course was fantastic. Prof Hickey is an astonishingly brilliant and kind instructor, and the class material is fascinating and something everyone should engage in at some point. The discussion format worked really well, the overall structure was great, and the feedback Hickey gave was always incredibly helpful.

No weaknesses, other than my wish for more time in class to discuss.
Strengths are endless an incredible syllabus combined with an incredible professor makes for an excellent class.
The strengths include a robust array of poets representing a variety of styles, helpful theory pieces that complement the readings well, and a very knowledgeable instructor. No weaknesses!

The class syllabus was structured to give a comprehensive overview of materials from a variety of Indigenous, First-Nation, and native populations.  The instructor was also very knowledgeable about the field and provided great additional reading suggestions to the class to continue their learning outside of the classroom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a, it sucks that we had the seminar on Zoom but I loved that Prof. Hickey was so accommodating and made new assignments that were better suited to life in the pandemic--for example, one assignment asked us to correspond with someone about the texts in the course, and I found it a great way to reconnect with people who I had lost touch with over the course of the pandemic. That was infinitely more valuable to me than any other assignment I'd completed during the COVID-19 semester.

I really appreciated the way Prof. Hickey was able to adjust her class in terms of what our discussions centered on, what our assignments looked like, and how we could engage with the material presented in a way that was conducive to our learning and took into account the difficulties of online learning.

The check-ins were amazing and helped me feel like both a sane person and a member of a communal space. Breakout rooms were always successful in helping us formulate ideas when we were drained and feeling low-energy. The alternative assignments were generously compassionate and actually made me feel like I took more away from the course than if I had just written an argumentation paper.
I think it all worked pretty well.

like I said Prof Hickey was SO helpful and understanding! Professors should all be this understanding and flexible even in times of in person learning. She also really encouraged us to be creative which freed me up to stress less and think and learn more
The whole way the course was taught succeeded.
Professor Hickey was extremely flexible in this course, which is something I so, so appreciated.
The instructor's incorporation of student-led presentations, video viewings, quasi-lectures, and open discussion was extremely conducive to an engaging learning environment during COVID-19.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ABSOLUTELY, this class taught me so much and was instrumental to my growth as a person and a writer. Alanna Hickey is the highlight of this course and our discussions were always thoughtful and engaging. She is a fantastic discussion leader and is honestly one of my  favorite professors. Prof. Hickey will meet you where you are at and help you become a better reader, writer, and thinker.
YES! It's a great class, even if poetry is not your thing.
YES, a wonderful course taught by an amazing and thoughtful professor. Everyone came very engaged to class and we all were able to check in on each other even while learning and having discussions.

Absolutely! Professor Hickey is one of the best professors I have ever had on this campus. She is so warm, brilliant and radically welcoming (especially for students who are new to this subject area, like me). She will do everything she can to support students, point them to texts that they would be interested in, support them when things get difficult, and treating students like real people. The class itself was wonderfully thoughtful. We were able to explore so many ideas, experiences, and modes of thought. I think I've learned more from this class than any other course I've taken here.
Yes, definitely! It's such a great class and what we read is really great! There's so much to talk about that we barely even scratched the surface of our material.

YES! Professor Hickey creates a uniquely thoughtful seminar space where students are encouraged to listen to each other and actually have a conversation, not to stunt on each other to prove they've done the reading. 10/10 would recommend
I cannot recommend this course highly enough. I learned so much and honestly had a great time.

YES!! Take any course with Professor Hickey, she might just be the best instructor at Yale. The course was always fully engaging, the readings were excellent and often the type of thing one wouldn't necessarily have exposure to otherwise, and the assignments were really mindful of covid limitations and our overall exhaustion. One of the best courses I've taken thus far.

I think this should be a required class for anyone in English, AMST, ER&M. I would unequivocally recommend this course to anyone the class had a solid mix of humanities and stem majors, and it made for an incredibly generative discussion every class. Take it for Prof. Hickey alone!
Yes! Prof. Hickey is a wonderful professor and I would recommend any course she teaches.
100%. Absolutely. Without a doubt!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Communication between classmates via postcard, outside events
Small breakout rooms for small-group discussions.
Virtual seminar over zoom
just virtual seminar and virtual office hours
We watched videos and poetry readings.
N/A
Break-out rooms, virtual video showings, virtual student presentations
